root.pub-comments: "The Sino-Tibetan family consists of two major subgroups, Chinese and Tibeto-Burman. By and large the distinction between the two is unambiguous and widely accepted, despite a dwindling number of older scholars who still see the connection as not yet proven" (6).

child.pub-comments: In chapter 16 of this book, Scott DeLancey places the Rung branch with Tibetan (255). Thurgood does not agree with this, as he states in chapter one. "In particular, it [Rung] is sometimes subgrouped with Tibetan, but as Nagano correctly points out in his contribution (and Sun Hongkai, et al.), the Tibetan-like vocabulary is most likely borrowed" (15).

"Various dialects of Tibetan are spoken in a broad area reaching from northern Pakistan to Qinghai, Sichuan, and Yunnan provinces in China...The most comprehensive current classification is that of Nishi (1986), who distinguishes six major groups: Central or U-Tsang, ...Western Archaic, ...Western Innoative, ...Southern, ...Khams, and Amdo" (DeLancey 270).

child.pub-comments: "The Tamang-Gurung-Thakali-Manang group of languages are referred to in various ways by those who study them... The subgroup, substantiated by reconstruction, has been worked on extensively and is reasonably well described' (Thurgood 10). 'Assessment of the internal relations within the group is complicated by a number of factors, among which is the fact that shared innovations may be the product of geographic contiguity as much as shared genetic back-ground" (Noonan 315).

"The Chantyal language is spoken by approximately 2000 of the 10,000 ethnic Chantyal. The Chantyal live in the Baglung and Myagdi Districts of Nepal; the villages where the Chantyal language is spoken are all located in the eastern portion of the Myagdi District and include the villages of Mangale Khāni, Dwāri, Ghyās, Kharkā, Caura Khāni, Kuine Khāni, Thārā Khāni, Pātle Kharkā, Mālāmpāhār, and Malkābāng. There is relatively little linguistic variation among thse villages, there where differences exist, it is the speech of Mangale Khāni, thta is represented here" (Noonan 315).

"The Chantyal language is spoken by approximately 2000 of the 10,000 ethnic Chantyal. child.pub-comments: "The Nar-Phu language is a member of the Tamangic group (along with Chanyal, Gurung, Manangba, Tamang, and Thakali). There are a number of phonological and lexical differences between the dialects of the two dialects of Nar and Phu… The dialects of the two villages are part of a dialect continuum with the dialects of the Manangba language and from a purely linguistic perspective it is not obvious that the dialects of Nar and Phu should be accord the status of a seperate language. The primary justifications for doing so are sociological: the people of the two villages see themselves as being a group apart from the Manangis (and the local Gurungs as well)... The Manangis, apparently, share the view that the people of Nar and Phu are not Manangis, so in deference to local feelings I will consider the speech of the villages of Nar and Phu as an independent language. The decision to call the language Nar-Phu (as opposed to "Narpa," which is perceived as the Manangba designation) was made in consultation with the native speakers" (Noonan 336).
child.publications: Thurgood, Graham Ward. 2003. A Subgrouping of the Sino-Tibetan Languages: The Interaction Between Language Contact, Change, and Inheritance. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 3-21. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5, Noonan, Michael. 2003. Nar-Phu. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 336-352. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: "The Tibetan division, a subset of Shafer's Bodic division (1955), contains at least three unquetsionable members: The numerous Tibetan dialects; the Tamang-Gurung-Thakali-Manang languages, a subgroup called by various names even within this volume; and the small group of languages that includes Takpa. Speculatively, Tshangla has been added to this group" (Thurgood 9).

"As for Takpa, it shares an innovated second person pronoun that resembles one for in TGMT languages, apparently descending from *khyot "thou." Several writers have suggested that Takpa belongs with the Tibetan group… Thus, tentatively, Takpa has been put here" (Thurgood 10). "The language is also spoken in Tibet, where it is known as 'Cuona Menba'" (Burling 179).

child.alt-names: Sharchopka, Cangluo Monpa, Motuo Monpa, Central Monpa
child.pub-comments: "Tschangla is spoken in western Arunachal, near the border of Bhutan. The same language is, sometimes known as "Sharchopka," is the predominate language of of the neighbouring region of Southeastern Bhutan. In China the language is known as 'Cangluo Monpa' or 'Motuo menba,' and in Arunachal it is often referred to as 'Central Monpa'" (Burling 179).

child.pub-comments: "It is often assumed that the Naga constitute a genetic subgroup [Kuki-Chin-Naga], but as Burling notes, there is still no clear evidence that these subgroups comprise a larger super-group, that is, it is not yet clear that the Ao, the Angami-Pochurim the Zeme, the Tangkhul, and the Mizo-Kuki-Chin groups as well as Meitei and Karbi constitute a subgroup" (Thurgood 12). "The individual groups seem sound, but how they relate to each other and whether they fall into one or several branches of Tibeto-Burman awaits further data and further analysis" (Burling 189).
Node not named by author.
Ethnologue places "Naga, Mzieme" (ISO 639-3: nme) within the Zeme subgrouping, but they do not have a subgroup under the Zeme subgrouping (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=nme).

child.pub-comments: In the text, this lect is referred to as "Lai/Laizo, Hakha Lai" (Thurgood 13). The author was not clear with this lect as to if "Laizo" and "Hakha Lai" are alternate names or dialects. In chapter 25 of "The Sino-Tibetan Languages," David A. Peterson seems to refer to "Hakha Lai" and "Lai" interchangably (409). By Thurgood's own naming convention described at the beginning of chapter one, 'we have simply given a common name, sometimes with another possibility added after a slash,' Laizo appears to be an alternate name (4). Based upon both authors' use of these names, it has been decided that they are in fact alternate names.

child.pub-comments: "Their language, known as 'Meitei' or 'Meiteilon' (or, often, as 'Manipuri') shows some lexical resemblances to Kuki and some to Tangkhul. These could be the result of borrowing from the language of the politcally and culturally dominant Meitei, and the resemblances are not great enough to make the assignment of Meitei to one of the groups obvious. None of the other classifications include Meitei within one specific group of 'Naga' or Kuki languages, though it has often been taken on to be a member of the larger Naga-Kuki grouping. As with Karbi, it seems safest to leave Meitei by itself" (Burling 187-188).
It should be noted that "...the Imphal dialect of Meithei...is considered to be the standard" (Chelliah 427).
child.publications: Chelliah, Shobhana Lakshmi. 2003. Meithei. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 427-438. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: "Other documented dialects include Sekmai (H.S. Singh 1988) and Pheyeng (P.R. Devi 1988), both spoken close to Imphal, and the Kwatga village dialect spoken on the Indo-Burmese border near Moreh (W.R. Singh 1989)" (Chelliah 427).
child.publications: Chelliah, Shobhana Lakshmi. 2003. Meithei. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 427-438. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: "The inclusion of Karbi/Arleng [Mikir] within the so-called Naga group reflects three beliefs. The Naga group itself is not yet established as agenetic subgroup and so far contains various not yet interconnected subgroups, hence, the use of the term 'so-called' to describe it. Second, there is no positive subgrouping evidence to place Karbi with any particular subgroup; that is, we know what it is not; for example, it is neither Lolo-Burmese nor Tibetan, but we do not know what it is. And, third, given its geographical location and the fact that various earlier scholars have placed it in this group, it has been put here until someone figures out what to do with it" (Thurgood 14).

child.pub-comments: "The most striking innovation is proto-Lolo-Burmeses tone 3. The core Lolo-Burmese languages all share reflexes of this particular tone and, of course, of the other two open tones reconstructed for this subgroup" (8).

"The Loloish languages are divided into Northern, Central, and Southern, on what initially might appear to be an exclusively geographical basis; however, here, the subgrouping finds substantiation in patterns of shared inovations. All Loloish languages show Mon-Khmer influence and some Chinese influence, with those Loloish languages now located in Thailand containing numerous Thai loanwords" (9).
On page 236, the author suggests "a scheme for southern Yipho."

child.pub-comments: According to Inga-Lill Hansson's article, "A Comparison of Akha, Hani, Khàtù, and Pìjɔ̀," published in Linguistics of the Tibeto-Burman Area, volume 12:1 - Spring 1989, the Chinese pronunciation of Pìjɔ̀ is 'Bìyuē' (7). Therefore, the SIL code for Biyue (ISO 639-3: byo) is being tentatively used in this instance.

child.pub-comments: "Based on purely linguistic criteria, there are two fundamental branches of the Lahu people: the Black Lahu (Lahu Na, Lâhū-nâ) and the Yellow Lahu (Lahu Shi, Lâhū-ši)" (208).
"In Thailand, the biggest Lahu groups are known as Red Lahu (Musəə Dɛɛŋ, Lahu Nyi, Lâhū-ni) and Lahu Shehleh (Lâhū šɛ-lɛ́), but these can be shown to be merely subvarieties of BL (Black Lahu)" (208).
child.publications: Matisoff, James A. 2003. Lahu. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 208-221. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: The author refers to Arakanese as a dialect of Burmese (8). In Ethnolgue 15, one code mhv stood for this lect. As of Ethnologue 16, Arakanese (ISO 639-3: mhv) retired and split into two codes: Rakhine (ISO 639-3: rki) and Marma (ISO 639-3: rmz). In Ethnologue 15 both of these were names of dialects of then Arakanese. Both codes were used to represent Arakanese in this instance, because of the retirement and the uncertainty regarding which variety the scholar intended to use.

child.pub-comments: The manner in which the author lists this language along with it's presumed alternate names leads to some confusion. His own convention states that alternate names either follow with a slash or in brackets (Thurgood 4). In this instance, there are names that follow with commas. According to Ethnologue, "Rangloi," "Gondla," and "Tinan" are all alternate names of "Tinani" (ISO 639-3: lbf) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=lbf). On this basis, it is assumed that the author meant for them to be alternate names.

child.pub-comments: "Kham, Magar, and Chepang have been subgrouped in various placed by various people for various reasons. The innovations among the aggreement markers tentatively suggest placement within Rung... The inclusion of Magar and Chepang is more problematic than the inclusion of Kham. Note that their placement together here is not the claim that these three represent any sort of subgroup" (Thurgood 16-17). "Kham, in all its varieties, is spoken in the upper valleys of the Rukum, Rolpa, and Baglung Districts of West Central Nepal by some forty or fifty thousand people... Geographically, the four Kham speaking subtribes are cut off from the rest of the Magar population by more than a week's walk over rugged, mountainous terrain. Though a comparison of basic vocabulary reveals no more of a special relationship between Kham and Magar than it does between Kham and other Himalayan languages, a careful examination of more innovative vocabulary makes it apparent that Magar is indeed Kham's closest relative" (Watters 683).

"Though no extensive survey of Kham has been conducted to date, the general picture emerging from my own fieldwork is that Kham is separated linguistically into three major dialect groupings - Sheshi, Gamale, and Parabate...Parbate, the largest group, can be further subdivided into Eastern and Western Parbate, and thought intelligibility across the two sub-branches is still fairly low, it is sufficiently high that speakers do not generally resort to secondary languages for communication" (Watters 683).

"Though no extensive survey of Kham has been conducted to date, the general picture emerging from my own fieldwork is that Kham is separated linguistically into three major dialect groupings - Sheshi, Gamale, and Parabate...Parbate, the largest group, can be further subdivided into Eastern and Western Parbate, and thought intelligibility across the two sub-branches is still fairly low, it is sufficiently high that speakers do not generally resort to secondary languages for communication" (Watters 683).
"Takale is both a village dialect, spoken in Taka village, and a regional dialect composed of several village dialects spoken in the same river valley" (Watters 683).

child.pub-comments: "Though no extensive survey of Kham has been conducted to date, the general picture emerging from my own fieldwork is that Kham is separated linguistically into three major dialect groupings - Sheshi, Gamale, and Parabate" (Watters 683).

child.pub-comments: "The Qiangic group is a complex and still not fully understood subgroup of Tibeto-Burman languages. The subgrouping provided here is tentative and is based in large part on the work of various authors. The concensus that Qiang proper and Prinmi belong in the same subgroup is easily and fully substantiated by careful examination of cognate sets. The inclusion of Muya in the group (suggested in Sun Hongkai 1988: 67) is also strongly supported by the cognate sets, but Sun's rational for the inclusion of the now extinct Tangut is not, as yet, clear to me... A second cluser of languages is also termed Qiangic. For these the definitive subgrouping evidence remains to be presented, but an inspection of the vocabulary suggests these are also part of this subgroup" (Thurgood 17). "Questions about the wider affliations of Qiangic also exist. These languages are often assumed to subgroup with the rGyalrong languages, but as LaPolla quite accurately points out, the rGyalrong languages subgroup more strongly with the rest of the Rung group, than with Qiang" (Thurgood 17).

"Spoken by the Pumi and Tibetan nationalities in northwestern Yunnan and southwestern Sichuan, Prinmi (Pumi) is a member of the Qiangic branch of the Tibeto-Burman languages... With widespread settlement in the mountain areas, speakers of Prinmi live close to many communities of distinct Tibeto-Burman languages. The two major dialectal groups are Northern Prinmi and Southern Prinmi, with some mutial unintelligibility" (Ding 2003: 588).
"The two major dialectal groups are Northern Prinmi and Southern Prinmi, with some mutial unintelligibility" (Ding 2003: 588).

"Niuwozi Prinmi... is from central Ninglang Yi Autonomous County, Yunnan, neighbouring Sichuan. It falls within Southern Prinmi under Lu's (1983) scheme, in the boarderland between Southern and Northern Prinmi" (Ding 2003: 588).

child.pub-comments: "Qiang is spoken in Aba Tibetan and Qiang Autonomous Prefecture in northwest Sichuan Province, China...There are two major Qiang dialects, Northern Qiang (spoken in Heishui County, and the Chibusu district of Mao County; roughly 70,000 speakers) and Souther Qiang (spoken in Li County, Wenchuan County, Mao County, and Songpan County; abut 60,000)" (LaPolla 2003: 573).

child.pub-comments: "The inclusion of Muya in the group (suggested in Sun Hongkai 1988: 67) is also strongly supported by the cognate sets, but Sun's rational for the inclusion of the now extinct Tangut is not, as yet, clear to me" (Thurgood 17). "There is no general agreement on the precise position of Tangut within the Tibeto-Burman languages. It has been claimed to have special affinities with Lolo-Burmese. Recent studies, however, reveal that it is most likely related to the Qiangic branch, with which Tangut shares some important cognates and grammatical features" (Hwang-Cherng 2003: 602).

child.pub-comments: "It is traditionally said that there are eighteen dialects. This classification came from the historical division of the area into eighteen administrative zones in the twelfth century, with a separate dialect spoken in each zone. On the basis of modern data, however, the language seems to have three dialects: northern, eastern, and western" (Nagano 469).

child.pub-comments: "There are a dozen or so Hayu villages in this area, but the language is currently spoken in only two, Murajor in Remechhap District...and Manedihi in the Marin Valley, Sindhuli District. There are probably about 200 speakers, all bilingual in Nepali, the Indo-Aryan national language... Since 1973 it has stopped being spoken by most children in Murajor, but it is still learnt in Manedihi, 30 kilometers to the west. There is no contact between the two villages. Dialect differences are slight..." (Michailovsky 518).

child.pub-comments: "Camling is one of the many endangered languages of the Kiranti cluster...The number of speakers is difficult to estimate, as there are many semi-speakers. In the areas I visited children do not learn the language any more. Balamta, a remote village in Udaypur, seems to be the only place where one can still find childrend speaking Camling. As a consequence, Camling has been heavily influenced by Nepali, especially in syntax and lexicon and on the pragmatic level. There is a great deal of dialectal variation. A major isogloss bundle runs along the rivers Sapsu and Sua Kosi, dividing northwestern (NW) from southeastern (SE) dialects." (Ebert 533).

child.pub-comments: "Kham, Magar, and Chepang have been subgrouped in various placed by various people for various reasons. The innovations among the aggreement markers tentatively suggest placement within Rung... The inclusion of Magar and Chepang is more problematic than the inclusion of Kham. Note that their placement together here is not the claim that these three represent any sort of subgroup" (Thurgood 16-17). "Geographically, the four Kham speaking subtribes are cut off from the rest of the Magar population by more than a week's walk over rugged, mountainous terrain. Though a comparison of basic vocabulary reveals no more of a special relationship between Kham and Magar than it does between Kham and other Himalayan languages, a careful examination of more innovative vocabulary makes it apparent that Magar is indeed Kham's closest relative" (Watters 683).
child.publications: Thurgood, Graham Ward. 2003. A Subgrouping of the Sino-Tibetan Languages: The Interaction Between Language Contact, Change, and Inheritance. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 3-21. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: "Various scholars have argued that the Tani languages constitute a distinct Tibeto-Burman subgroup, with Sun's recent construction of proto-Tani (1993) placing its status as a subgroup on a firm footing' (18). 'The nature of Tani's subgrouping with relationships with neighbouring Tibeto-Burman languages is not evident yet. As Sun notes, while Tani languages bear similarities to Taraon and Idu languages on the east and Hruso, Dhammai, and Levai or Bangru on the west, these similarities may be the result, not so much of a close subgrouping relationship, as due to long-term contact. Certainly contact has had an effect on Tani languages. Tani languages are also under contact pressure from Indo-Aryan and even from English, citing the importation of laonwords with the otherwise absent codas -s, -l, and -m" (19).

Ethnologue lists "Gallong" as a dialect of Adi (ISO 639-3: adi) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=adi). It also lists "Gallong" and "Adi-Gallong" as alternate names for Adi, Galo (ISO 639-3: adl) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=adl).

child.pub-comments: "Karen is thus located on the periphery of the Tibeto-Burman area. It is the southernmost and, along with Lolo-Burmese and Tujia, the easternmost of the Tibeto-Burman subgroups. This peripheral location has put Karen in extensive contact with non-Tibeto-Burman languages, of the Tai and Mon-Khmer families. The Tai influence is evident in Karen historyical phonology... Karen's verb-medial syntactic typology, in which it is alone in Tibeto-Burman, is surely another result of contact with Tai, Mo-Khmer, or both" (Solnit 2003: 623). "The Central Karen area is the centre of Karen linguistic diversity and so the presumptive historical centre from which the languages have spread" (624).

child.pub-comments: Graham Thurgood and David Solnit both say that Kayah Li, Brè, Yintale, Palayachi, and Mopwa are members of the Central Karenic subgroup along with other languages, but none of these other languages are listed. Therefore, presumably this subgroup has more languages, but it is not certain what they are.

Eastern Kayah Li is spoken in the area of Kayah State (Karenni) of Burma east of the Pun river (west of the parallel to the Salween) and extending a short distance into Mae Hong son province, northwestern Thailand... An older term is Karenni, which is anglicized Burmese; Burmese <ni> is also "red" (Solnit 2003: 623).

"There is variation, mostly staying within the bounds of mutual intelligibility, across the Kayah Li speech area. Kayah Li speakers in Thailand recognize two mutualy intelligible dialects, kè khu 'upper' and kè kɛ 'lower'" (Solnit 2003: 623).
child.publications: Solnit, David B. 2003. Eastern Kayah Li. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 623-631. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: "The dialects of Pwo Karen can be divided into two groups: the eastern dialects and the western dialects" (Kato 2003: 632).
"The western dialects are spoken widely in the area of the Irrawady delta, and the main towns where they are spoken are Bassein, Myaungmya, Kyonbyaw" (Kato 2003: 632).
child.publications: Kato, Atsuhiko. 2003. Pwo Karen. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 632-648. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: "The eastern dialects are spoken in Karen State, the Mon State, the Tenasserim Division of Burma and western Thailand. The main towns where the Eastern dialects are spoken are Hpa-an, which is the capital of the Karen State, Hliangbway, Kawkareik... The dialect treated in this chapter is one of the Eastern dialects spoken around Hpa-an, referred to here as the Hpa-an dialect" (Kato 2003: 632).

child.pub-comments: "Sun (1993a: 12 fn. 18) suggests that Sherdukpen (2,000 speakers) and Bugun (8,000 speakers), both of which are found just to the east of Tshangla, together with the little known language 'Lishpa,' might form a group of their own. To these he tentatively adds Sulung (4,000 speakers), which is spoken well to the north, along the Tibetan border... Relatively recent vocabularies of Sherdukpen... and Sulung... allow a more systematic comparison among these three languages than would have been possible earlier, and there can now be little doubt that they belong together. Their vocabulary is remarkably divergent from Tibeto-Burman languages, however, and a few of us have even wondered whether Sulung belongs to Tibeto-Burman at all. However, each of the three languages has a number of apparent Tibeto-Burman cognates so, if the three do form a group, their Tibeto-Burman affliation seems secure. Simon (1976) offers fragmentary data from Lishpa and from a language that he calls 'But-pa,' both of which, he says, are found to the west of Bugun. His data suggest that these also belong with this group, and his handful of But-pa examples look so much like Sherdukpen that it might even count as a dialect" (Burling 2003: 180).

To these he tentatively adds Sulung (4,000 speakers), which is spoken well to the north, along the Tibetan border... child.pub-comments: "This is, by far, the most extensive recognizable subgroup of any that is based primarily in Northeastern India, and it constitutes a major subgroup of Tibeto-Burman" (Burling 175). "Burling has established this subgrouping on the basis of shared lexical innovations, particularly the innovation of sal 'sun' (Burling 1983)" (Thurgood 11).
Node not named by author.

"Bodo-Konyak-Jinghpaw has three main branches. One of these, Bodo-Koch [Bodo, Bodo-Garo, Barish], is well established, having been recognized at least since the time of the Linguistic Survey of India (Grierson, Vol. III, Part II, 1903). The Bodo-Koch branch, in turn, divides into four parts: Bodo, Garo, Koch, and Deori" (Burling 176).
Node not named by author.

Node not named by author. "The data given by Burling (1959) suggests that Garo is closer to Bodo, than to Koch, which is why I prefer to call the larger group "Bodo-Koch," but most published classifications imply that Garo is closer to Koch. This is probably because of confusion over A'tong and Ruga. Speakers of these two languages live in the southern part of the Garo Hills and are accepted by everyone as being ethnically Garo. Their languages, however, are by no means mutually intelligible with Garo" (Burling 176).
Node not named by author.

"Tiwa [Lalung], also in Assam, and Kokborok [Tripuri] in Tripura state to the south appear to be marginally more distant from Boro, Dimasa, and Kachari, than the latter are from each other" (Burling 177).

child.pub-comments: "Matchi, Chisak, and Dual are found in smaller areas in the central and southern part of the district, but all of these dialects grade into one another without sharp breaks" (Burling 387). According to Ethnologue, "Dual" is an alternate name for the "Achik" dialect of "Garo" (ISO 639-3: grt) in India. In Bangladesh it seems to be considered simply as a dialect name with no noted connection to "Achik" (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=grt). Therefore, the dialect code for "Achik" and separate dialect code for "Dual" were both used in this instance.
child.publications: Burling, Robbins. 2003. Garo. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 387-400. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: "Ruga is now moribund. I doubt if anyone younger than fifty would claim to speak the language. A'tong, apparently, is a bit healthier' (Burling 176). Many classify Garo with Koch and 'this is probably because of confusion over A'tong and Ruga. Speakers of these two languages live in the southern part of the Garo Hills and are accepted by everyone as being ethnically Garo. Their languages, however, are by no means mutually intelligible with Garo" (176).

child.pub-comments: "The languages of the Konyak group, named for its largest member, are less well known than the Bodo-Koch languages, and they appear to be considerably more heterogeneous, although unity of the group seems clear" (Burling 177).
Node not named by author. "French offers convincing evidence that Tangsa and Nocte form a subgroup within the larger Konyak group" (Burling 177).

This lect only appears in Thurgood's classification in chapter 1 of this publication (11). Ethnologue lists "Yogli" as a dialect of "Naga, Tase" (ISO 639-3: nst) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=nst). Based on its placement in Thurgood's listing it appears that he is listing it as a separate lect from "Tangsa," and is therefore listed as a language.
child.publications: Thurgood, Graham Ward. 2003. A Subgrouping of the Sino-Tibetan Languages: The Interaction Between Language Contact, Change, and Inheritance. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 3-21. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: According to Ethnologue, "Wakching" is an alternate name for "Tableng," a dialect of "Naga, Konyak" (ISO 639-3: nbe). This lect only appears in Thurgood's classification in chapter 1 of this publication, where he appears to list it as a language (11).

child.pub-comments: "Jinghpaw has figured much more prominently in Tibeto-Burman studies than have the poorly known languages of the Konyak group, and it has been classified in a number of ways. Often it has been placed with the Lolo-Burmese because it shares considerable vocabulary with the so-called 'northern Burmish' languages (Atsi, Maru, Hpon, etc.) and even with Burmese. It should be remembered, however, that Jinghpaw is used as a lingua franca in the linguisticsally heterogeneous Kachin State of northern Myanmar. This is an area of massive multilingualism, and Jinghpaw has had ample opportunity to borrow from the northern Burmish languages... Borrowing can easily account for the similarities of Jinghpaw to Burmese and northern Burmish languages, while its similariets to Bodo-Koch and the Konyak group have to be older" (Burling 177-178).

child.pub-comments: "Hruso [Aka] (3,000 speakers) and Dhammai/Miji (4,000 speakers) are spoken just east and north of Bugun and Sherdukpen. Shafer (1947) gave the name 'Hruso A' to the language of the people who call themselves 'Dhammai,' while he called Hruso proper 'Hruso B.' In fact, these are quite differnt languages, as is evident from Simon's vocabularies of Dhammai (1979) and Hruso (1970), not dialects as seems to be implied by calling them both 'Hruso.' Nevertheless, they show enough similarities to let them be grouped together. In addition to these two, Sun has now added a third language to the Hrusish group, the little known Bangru/Levai, which is spoken further north along the Tibetan border (1993b: 159) Sun describes it as very similar to Dhammai" (Burling 2003: 180).

child.pub-comments: "Tujia is on the southeastern edge of Tibeto-Burman and, as such, has come under considerable contact pressure. Its subgrouping remains a mystery" (20).

child.pub-comments: "Pyu is an extinct language of a Tibeto-Burman people who once dominated much of what is now norther Burma, while southern Burma was part of the Mon Kingdom. The former influence of the Pyu is reflected in the fact that early Burmese inscriptions were occasionally written in the Pyu script and in the references to them found in Chinese records of the time" (20).

child.pub-comments: "Chinese is really a family of related dialect groups, with the diversity within the different dialect groups often marked enough to make even dialects within the same dialect group mutually unintelligible. The grouping below into six dialect families matches Norman's practice, aside from the placement of Hakka' (Thurgood 6)."[Chinese] Dialects in turn are considered to belong to a small number of more or less defined dialect groups like Wú and Min' (Norman 72). "Before proceeding to a discussion of the various groups of dialects, it should be made clear that Chinese is not entirely amendable to a Stammbaum formulation. The fact that these dialects have been spoken in close proximity to one another for two millennia and the pervasive influence of various quasi-standards and koinés on all Chinese dialects over a very long period easily obscures underlying relationships. Nonetheless, to go the other extreme and claim that Chinese dialects cannot be classified in any meaningful way would be equally erroneous." (Norman 76-77).

"While they [Gàn dialects] clearly differ from Wú and Xiāng in the way that they treat the old voiced obstruents, it is more difficult to keep them separate from Hakka where the two groups show the same development with regard to this feature" (Norman 79).

"The dialect of Jiànníng in western Fújiàn...has a reflex of *m² for 'not' and *zik⁸ for 'eat,' as in Hakka, but uses *zhi⁸ for the copula, as in Gàn...There are clearly some dialects that are transitional between Gàn and Hakka...' (80).
child.publications: Norman, Jerry. 2003. Phonology of Chinese Dialects. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 72-83. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5

child.pub-comments: Thurgood places Hakka within his "Gan dialect family" and notes that this grouping disagrees with Norman's grouping in chapter five, "Phonology of the Chinese Dialects." "The grouping below [of Chinese] into six dialect families matches Norman's practice, aside from the placement of Hakka" (Thurgood 6). Norman also admits that in the final analysis, however, it is often difficult to draw a sharp line between Gàn and Hakka dialects" (Norman 80). This tree reflects Thurgood's grouping.
"Méixiàn is a Hakka dialect" (76).
child.publications: Norman, Jerry. 2003. Phonology of Chinese Dialects. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 72-83. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5
Norman, Jerry. 2003. Phonology of Chinese Dialects. In Randy J. LaPolla & Graham Ward Thurgood (eds.), The Sino-Tibetan Languages, 72-83. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-7007-1129-5
child.geography: South of Gàn in Jiāngxī province, northern Guǎngdōng, southwestern Fújiàn

child.pub-comments: "The dialect of Dūchāng is reported to have ten tones but this is due to splits in several tones based on the presence of aspiration" (79). According to Glossika, Dūchāng is a topolect of the Gan dialect Changjing (http://language.glossika.com/zh1414/).

child.pub-comments: "Jiāngyǒng is a so-called Tǔ dialect, a group of Xiāng dialects spoken in an area where Southwest Mandarin is also spoken, mainly in southern Húnán" (76).

"Jiāngyǒng is a so-called Tǔ dialect, a group of Xiāng dialects spoken in an area where Southwest Mandarin is also spoken, mainly in southern Húnán" (76). According to Wikipedia, Jiāngyǒng is a county in the Hunan province (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jiangyong). The region name seems to be used as the dialect name, which could not be found.

child.pub-comments: In Dah-an Ho's chapter, "The Characteristics of Mandarin Dialects," he proposes dividing them"into three regions: Northern Mandarin, Southwestern Mandarin and Jing-Huai Mandarin' (129). But, he later states"whether dividing Mandarin dialects into three regions is appropriate and to what extent subdivisions of each region are to be made are still controversial questions. In our opinion, basic data on several dialects is still insufficient, and therefore no final conclusion can be made on the classification or subgrouping, or even on the criteria to be used in classification' (130). Thurgood does not use or even mention these proposed subdivisions, presumably because their existance is questionable. Therefore, these divisions have not been used in the grouping of Mandarin dialects.

child.pub-comments: "The national standard language, Putonghua, is based on the phonology of the dialect of Beijing but the lexicon and grammar are based on general northern vernacular" (Thurgood 6). "We have obtained sufficient evidence to show that even though Putonghua represents the Mandarin dialect area, this does not mean that the dialects in this area were directly derived from Putonghua, or belong to the same group as Putonghua. Putonghua is only a kind of Mandarin dialect and has been the lingua franca of the country for no more than 200 years" (Ho 127).

child.pub-comments: "...although both the Guangzhou and Hong Kong varieties are quite similar, differences of pronunciation, vocabulary, and grammar are to be found" (146). Ethnologue lists "Hong Kong Cantonese" as an alternate name of the Yuehai dialect of Yue. Therefore, the dialect code for Yuehai has been used here.

child.pub-comments: According to Ethnologue, there are four Chinese languages that have "Min" as part of their name: "Chinese, Min Bei" (ISO 639-3: mnp), "Chinese, Min Dong" (ISO 639-3: cdo), "Chinese, Min Nan" (ISO 639-3: nan), and "Chinese, Min Zhong" (ISO 639-3: czo) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=zho). The ambiguous name "Min dialect family" used by Thurgood does not shed light on which variety he is referring to (6). Therefore, the codes for each have been used here.

According to Ethnologue, "Chinese, Min Nan" (ISO 639-3: nan) has a dialect "Hokkien" and a dialect within the "Xiamen" dialect group, "Fujian," that also has "Hokkien" as an alternate name (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=nan).
